Internet's busiest music nerd and review
time Big KRIT live from the underground
Big KRIT is a Mississippi rapper who's
been putting the south back on the map
recently in terms of hip hop and not for
bass heavy hooky club tunes or or trap
rap but instead with a modernized
version of the catchy soulful and poetic
sounds with some of the best southern
hip hop artists out there like outcast
and goody mob and UGK Cray has kind of
perfected his own sound inspired by
these influences with three mixtapes
he's released over the past few years he
fills his lyrics with his personality
and his passions like yes cars and girls
but also family the trials and
tribulations of making it his Southern
heritage and poverty and Chris a
producer as well always writing his own
instrumental which has only made him
sound even more unique in contemporary
hip-hop and he's not afraid to sing on
his tracks either and he does it well on
top of all that big craze usually pretty
meticulous when it comes to assembling
an entire album you're not going to get
a disjointed assembly of singles from
this guy he's got his intimate tracks
his party tracks as his conscious tracks
his love songs and he makes sure to
transition them all into one another in
a very tasteful way really gives his
releases the feel of a journey now this
is big crits major label debut live from
the underground and even though with
this album he is sort of hitting it big
obviously with the title he's still kind
of looking to maintain his underdog
image he still wants to be the Big KRIT
that fans followed up until this point
but this
is a commercial record this is a major
label debut all bets are off and change
does come from a lot of directions on
this album to start the production there
are a lot of new additions on this album
from the really glitchy effects in the
female narrator that kind of starts the
LP off the sound effects and the really
short skits that kind of bring one track
to another at some points there are horn
sections on here guitar solos are Monica
solo string sections and piano lots of
guest singers and some chorus vocals too
overall this album brings crit's usual
mix of a very smooth melodic and soulful
tracks and hard-hitting hyped up and
jittery spicy southern hip hop tracks as
well but with just a little more flow
more sound and he definitely uses his
label affiliation now to bring in some
interesting guests Canadian R&B singer
Melanie Fiona Anthony Hamilton another
singer as well as blues legend BB King
and some southern hip hop forefathers
and influences as well on here like bun
B and Ludacris which Big KRIT has
collaborated with before
8ball & MJG - a lot of doors are open
right now for Big KRIT with this LP and
he's taking full advantage of them and
even though this album by a longshot is
not the first time he's ever brought a
collaborator on to attract and something
new add something different I'm not sure
if every new sound on this album goes
over all that well the track cool to be
southern has these horn sections that
feel okay they unfortunately don't
really bring the thrill that you would
expect from a horn section even as they
are soloing underneath crit's verses and
if i had to put my finger on a radio
single for this LP it's got to be money
on the floor and it's a really well
produced track with some glistening
sense and burbling bass lines
however lyrically the song doesn't
really add
to much more than just a really tame
strip club track none of the lyrics on
this track really grabbed me outside of
a 25 lighters references being very
funny or very catchy or
thought-provoking
and as far as the handful of songs on
here that have R&B singers on them go I
just really do not care for a single R&B
hook on this album and I have to kind of
single out the Anthony Hamilton track I
just did not care for his singing style
on that song it kind of borders on like
parody for me with him singing in this
really kind of robust voice about coming
home strong and that's another moment I
didn't really care for now despite all
of my complaints I do think Big KRIT
writes some of his best songs ever on
this album without question the album's
first two singles I got this and yeah
that's me are stellar
both could have easily slipped into one
of his past two tapes but feel
completely re-energized new and fresh
he's got these energetic chants this
really hyped up flow and I love the
really detail than just subtle vocal
samples playing in the background of I
got this that is the kind of layering
that I expect from a Big KRIT
instrumental really impressive stuff
these two tracks are essentially just
Big KRIT fight songs where you just
cannot help but cheer him on the piano
the vocal the strings and the song Rich
Dad Poor Dad and the story is well are
breathtaking quick basically talking
about his father and relating his
difficulties as a parent to the
difficulties Big KRIT may face if he
were to become one and from the marching
snare drum to the really unique melody
that leaves that track it is just a
great great song I'm loving the live
instrumentation on this track I wish
more songs on here featured it if they
were to be this powerful I love the song
praying man which features BB King his
voice on that track field
so grainy and eerie I love the forlorn
humming on the track it's just a really
moody instrumental and Baker it gives
this LP a really smooth finish with the
last track with him singing quite a bit
a lot like the song highs and lows from
return of forever but with way more
sounds harmonica and guitar soloing you
know overall for me this is a relatively
solid listen there are some moments on
here that clearly move in a more
commercial direction but not so far that
they ruin the album really just kind of
make it slightly underwhelming in some
moments just kind of feeling a strong
six to a light seven on this LP I'm also
feeling sweaty but what did you guys
